Who could have guessed that the most cathartic rebuke to the culture of abuse and power in the entertainment industry would be the Pixar skeleton movie?

A colorful and vibrant coming of age drama, that treads along in an engaging manner with innovative animations, authentically enjoyable soundtrack and hearty takeaways. It is culturally rooted and beautifully utilizes the metaphysical elements of life and death, to complement its multi generational setting and convey its positive values. With dreams, family and forgiveness as its key themes, it does indeed take you on a highly gratifying journey.

Achieves the baseline Pixar guarantee of fine, cute, gorgeous, etc, but it really does feel as if they have a contractual obligation to only get the welcome increase in levels of visual sophistication/imagination and cultural specificity as long as they counterbalance it with an equal ratio of boilerplate, mechanical narrative choices. That being said the ending is indeed very nice, I'm not completely made of stone.

It took them 7 years, but with Coco, Pixar finally created a film reminiscent of the magic of their projects in the 2000s. I couldn’t help but to be immediately hooked with our introduction to the world and its characters. — What we end up getting is a truly brilliant and dynamic story about lineage, emotion, and self-discovery. I had my problems with the second act in particular but that final act provided a heartwarming conclusion that tied the story and its magical world-building together perfectly. A must-watch for everybody.

58/100Like Brave, often feels more Disney than Pixar—I imagine it's hard to craft a story around a child protagonist without falling back on the ol' vocation-thwarted-by-overprotective-or-uncomprehending-family-members routine. I love emotional films. I’m a sucker for them. Coco is an emotional film and the tears are inevitable. Miguel’s story takes you on an adventure full of heart, sadness, love, and compassion. This movie is beautiful to watch in both a literal sense and emotional sense. Every shot is filled with excruciating detail and at its core Coco is a heartwarming, sentimental, and culturally sensitive film. It is a stunning work of art that’ll move you from happiness to tears and take you from memories of the past to the joys of the future. It’s a subtle, yet charming and inspiring film.

This film is living proof of animation’s greatest strength: creating fantastical and inventive worlds that simply wouldn’t be possible in live-action.

Dazzling visuals and truly awe-inspiring world design. A point A-to-B-to-C plot line could have felt formulaic, but an emphasis on individuality without forsaking family or ties as a throughline keeps us cruising. Certainly one of the greatest and most impactful final 10-15 minutes of a movie I've ever seen. Gael García Bernal frantically delivering PG-rated dialogue is very reminiscent of Joe Pesci in Home Alone 1 & 2 - as if I needed any more reason to be on board (with the movie or with the force of nature that is Gael García Bernal in film). This movie makes me so happy.

”We give you our blessing. No conditions.”A vibrant but bittersweet look at family and the fear of being forgotten. At a deeper level this film tackles a recurring theme of recent Disney/Pixar movies: possessive love. Time and time again we see well intentioned parents & grandparents manage their insecurities under the guise of doing ‘what’s best for the family.’ Coco is without question the most thoughtful and emotional exploration of this trope, while also providing a comforting view of the afterlife.

A Pixar tá meio que virando um Michael Haneke do bem. Não acho um problema, apesar de reconhecer alguns elementos pré-definidos que podem culminar numa possível fórmula. E engraçado que parece que eles mesmos comentam isso (a cena do auditório com as reviravoltas, a “manipulação” da platéia). E de qualquer forma, a caracterização de tudo é tão boa, especialmente na leitura mística do universo, que já ganha vários pontos.

Simply stunning animation. Photo-realistic yet thoroughly stylized in the same scenes. The background score was a little forgettable for me, but the guitar and vocal focused musical sequences were rich and beautiful. The first act or so suffers a bit from feeling a little generic and predictable, leaning into the usual coming of age tropes and some unimpressive humor, but the latter half of the film has enough twists and emotional punch to carry the film through. Perhaps not remarkably original overall, but the touching moments and immense detail put into it is enough to make it stand out.

A profoundly moving narrative delving into the complexities of familial dynamics, showcasing how, at times, loved ones can inadvertently hinder rather than support one's aspirations. Frequently, such obstacles arise from motives that are either unfathomable or based on misconceptions. Yet, amidst these challenges, the story unfolds as a heartening testament to the transformative power of pursuing one's dreams and uncovering the truth, ultimately leading to a more fulfilling life journey.

America fears death and denies grief. Coco, the newest heart-swelling Pixar film, confronts these issues in its basic concept. This is because the Mexican holiday--Día de Muertos or Día de los Muertos--is front and center in Coco’s adventure. Día de Muertos is a celebration in which families get together and remember their loved ones that have died. They come together to acknowledge the deceased through making ofrendas or altars where they make the deceased person’s favorite foods. They also place…

Following the success of last year's Moana, Disney's latest is an exploration of another culture rarely seen on screen. Coco presents a dazzling and heartwarming depiction of the Mexican people, and one of their most important fiestas, in the most visually stunning animation I have ever seen. I knew nothing about the culture going into this or what Dia de los Muertos was truly about and films like these are incredibly important, especially for children, to learn about cultures apart from their own. I hope Disney continues this trend and I can't wait to see what other heartfelt stories they bring to the screen.

This review may contain spoilers. I can handle the truth.  I don't usually try to blurb, but if I did, my Coco comment here would be something along the lines of: Come for the surprisingly expressive 3D, gorgeous animation and gently twisted comedy, and stay for the thoughtful ruminations on family, generational trauma, hope and regret, the dark side of the showbiz industry, and the theological implications of mass media. Mild spoiler: I am at the point where I don't usually have a lot of patience for the live mic/hidden tape recorder as a plot device, but it works LIKE A CHARM here.
While not quite as ambitious or emotionally resonant as Pixar's finest films, Coco is a visually dazzling tribute to culture and family with an abundance of imagination and heart.

Worth watching for the amazing animation/ visuals.

I didn't know much about the movie, but I was pleasantly surprised. It was bold, colorful, creative and teaches the importance of following your dreams. The story follows a young boy, Miguel, who has dreams about playing the guitar but his family is against it. Such a heartwarming movie.

Co-opting a foreign culture to tell a story about a guitar-playing youngster recalling his deceased family, Coco is, visually at least, inarguably one of Pixar's most ambitious and colourful features. It is directed by Lee Unkrich (Toy Story 3) and Adrian Molina, and ranks as the 19th feature from the animation studio, and naturally, it looks fantastic. It follows striving musician Miguel, a twelve-year-old musician voiced by Anthony Gonzalez. After being confronted with his family's traditional embargo on music, Miguel infiltrates the…

Coco is a richly-woven tapestry of culture and celebration, life and death, and family and love. Deeply sophisticated in conjuring a vividly-coloured vision and spectacle - for which director Lee Unkrich should be acknowledged - and handling the sort of tricky themes Pixar excels in delivering each and every time, Coco has something for everyone. Adrian Molina and Matthew Aldrich deliver a script packed with emotion and glowing world-building, richly enhanced by a soundtrack and score brimming with charm and infectiousness, as well as some lovely voice performances to boot. Featured in my top 20 films of 2018

Pixar computer-animated children's fantasy film based on the Mexican cultural tradition of 'The Day of the Dead'. It's about the importance of family and remembering those who have died. And the importance of music in helping people remember, particularly those with dementia.Heavy themes for a children's film you may think, but the story and the animation are so beautiful and so colourful that it's a comforting view of some difficult ideas for children (or anyone) to think about.An old-fashioned cinema experience, engrossing and emotionally satisfying without being sentimental. A wonderful work of art for all ages.

I would call this middle-grade Pixar, which means it's still better than most films out there. It begins slow, and Miguel entering the land of the dead doesn't have the same weight as, let's say, a child entering the monster universe. This feels less catastrophic and more "light", but the film hits all the right emotional beats and it hits them hard. The movie gets better as it goes on, which is always a nice surprise. However, Pixar has at least 6 films better than this, but for what it is, I'm thankful.

"Recuérdame"COCO is stunningly realized and a great example of how visual storytelling can surpass almost any narrative form in functionality. In the world of the living, Mexican roads and towns are strikingly realistic, capturing a look to Mexico not often seen in American film. The warm color palette is welcoming and full of its own history. The characters practically invite you to sing and dance through the streets. As Miguel walks across a floral bridge to the afterlife, imagery…

At its core, it's a story about family, identity, and the power of music to transcend generations. As Miguel embarks on a quest to uncover his family's mysterious past, I found myself laughing, crying, and cheering him on every step of the way. From the catchy tunes to the heartfelt ballads, every song felt like it was straight from the heart. And when Miguel finally takes the stage to perform "Remember Me," I couldn't help but be moved to tears.

Coco carries a lot of the Disney cliches but it’s mastery of animation and storytelling makes them feel new and suspenseful as if it’s the first time a villain’s evil deeds have secretly been recorded or a lack of communication obscured what would otherwise be a quick point. In my opinion Coco is one of the best animated films of all time and probably the most visually beautiful one. When we die, we live on in the memories of those who knew and loved us. This sentiment is at the core of Pixar’s Coco, a colorfully animated masterpiece celebrating Mexico’s Day of the Dead tradition. The world-building and character-driven elements of the narrative are so intricate and fully realized. Because the film wisely only dips into deep emotion in a few key moments, those scenes land with such impact. Beautiful and vibrant, Coco is first-rate Pixar.

Top-tier Pixar plays like a Mexican musical version of Spirited Away, rife with joyful, inventive energy. It's also their best work as an animation studio, reveling in the depth of a frame, dotting each environment with a wealth of details, and going hogwild with color and lighting in a way they haven't in a long while. It also manages to be very tightly constructed without sacrificing smaller moments allowing the characters to actually breathe. Just an all-around strong film. I wish Pixar would do more original work like this.
Coco is another winning example of Pixar's talent, easily the best animated film of 2017, and a piece of movie-making magic I’ll remember for years to come.FULL REVIEW HERE!

It’s been a couple years, but Pixar has delivered in a big way again. Imagine a cross between Spirited Away and Inside Out with almost all the bad parts taken out, and you have this movie. Every single moment is earned in this emotionally touching story about how sometimes you have to go against your family’s wishes to be who you want to be. This story has been done a million times before, but it does so many subversive, original, and inventive things that I can easily forgive some standard third-act flaws. It would be a sin to give this anything less than a 4.5.

Pixar has often tackled mortality within their films, be it growing old or dealing with loss, but none of them have taken on such themes with such vigor as Coco does. By making their film finally actually feature dead characters, the deep humanity often found in Pixar films comes to life stronger than ever before. The Dante-esque tale of Miguel resonates in a truly delightful and emotionally affecting way.Moreover though, the tone of Coco doesn't feel very Pixar-like or…

UP VS COCO: BATTLE OF THE PIXAR TEARS.I cannot get my mind around how groundbreaking the animation from Pixar Animation Studios is getting. Every aspect down from the tiny details in clothing and reflections to the grand colour filled backdrops are breathtaking.Coco restored my faith in Pixar that their original films can still be fantastic. I am slightly hesitant on their upcoming sequel films (especially Toy Story 4 after the third's perfect ending) but regardless how they turn out,I know that Pixar will deliver a beautiful looking film and a story with a big heart. Which is exactly what I can say about Coco.

Mesmo sofrendo com todos os clichês e formatos projetados para manipular e tirar lágrimas do espectador que a Disney e a Pixar abusam já faz vários filmes, aqui essas fraquezas funcionam como pontos fortes. O fato do povo mexicano ser tão intenso, dramático, artístico e exagerado fica mais evidente com todos esses artíficios e o filme ganha mais pontos ainda por ter um coração enorme. Engloba família, mortalidade, memórias e arte de uma forma tão acolhedora que é quase impossível não se emocionar em diversas cenas. Um dos maiores acertos da parceria desses estúdios.

Dia de los Muertos, der Tag der Toten. Mexikos Gedenken der Verstorbenen --> 31. Okt. bis 2. November. Demnach eine gelungene Programmüberleitung von Halloween zu Allerheiligen/-seelen. Disney überquert darin die Brücke vom Leben ins Reich der Toten. Und klein Miguel den „grenzüberschreitenden“ Weg familiärer Selbstfindung.Die Barriere bildgewaltig und außerordentlich kreativ eingefädelt, präsentiert sich COCO als bunter, kultureller Augenschmaus und rührende Geschichte voll warmherziger Ideen. Sodass einem in beiden Fällen die Augen überlaufen. Eine grandiose Visualisierung/Interpretation spirituellen Gedankengutes – mit Musik als Schlüssel zur Heilung. Der schönste Ahnenbesuch der Animationsgeschichte! Durch und durch magisch. :)

Just when people start to question Pixar's lofty position on the animation throne, they put out another instant classic. Coco is a vibrant visually astonishing feast for the eyes, with a timely and timeless story to match. The attention to detail put into the Land of the Dead is a sight to behold. Disney films have had many dark moments throughout the studio's long tenure, but some of the themes in Coco are even darker than I could have expected.…

It's hard not to be in awe of Coco. The pure existence of this film is an achievement, let alone the time and effort that was put into the film to create one of Disney's most vibrant films yet. Coco is nothing short of stunning. I regret not being able to see this film in theaters, since it would have been absolutely beautiful to see on the big screen. I can't wait to watch Coco over and over again, since it's truly a magnificent film that struck a very emotional chord within me.
Retreads familiar ground, but with such humour and warmth it's surely impossible not to love. It's eloquent musings on death make it one of the more poignant Pixar films.

No movie has managed to capture Mexican sentiment so purely and magically like this. The craft behind this is stunning, even at Pixar levels. Respect for family is just as important as respect for dreams of its individual members.In an era where young people are so easily seduced by the wrong and fake concept of "celebrity", Coco reveals the emptiness of such adulation, poignantly teaching kids to preserve and respect the memory of their elders while reminding them that the source of true creativity is so often personal.Coco is an offering to the Mexican people and a sort of reconciliation between Mexico and the United States and the Future Academy Award for Best Animated Feature Film of the Year.

This is admittedly a very predictable movie, but it’s a predictable movie done well. Even though it was easy to guess everything that was going to happen I still immensely enjoyed watching it play out - partially because of the dialogue/writing, but perhaps even more so because of how beautiful it was. I loved the art in this movie, especially the backdrops and all of the animal/spirit designs. Pixar did good.

There was something about this movie I just couldn't connect with, it didn't deliver enough laughs for me and the tone seemed a bit too doom and gloom for a kids movie. The animation is stunning, especially all the skeletons, and it's an interesting direction for Pixar but far from their best in my opinion. A one time watch only.

A few narrative familiarities, some plot conveniences, and the occasional dip in pace never manage to derail the vibrant rhythm and soul found in nearly every scene of Pixar’s latest, “Coco”. Delicate cultural threads dig deep throughout and are fantastically married with resonant and universal insights on the power of both family and identity. The messages spawned from these paired elements are all well-rounded, tender, and unquestionably rich. When all is sung and the credits roll, you’ll leave the experience…

Taking place during Dia de los Muertos, Coco is an endearing and colorfully animated love letter to Mexican culture and traditions that definitely tugs on the heart strings. I'll leave it to Edgar Cochran to explore the richness of cultural details littered throughout the film.(also, this film is a great companion to A Ghost Story, a film which came out earlier this year that also deals with being remembered by our loved ones)

As colorful and imaginative as this is, it's sad to think how hand-drawn animation is all but extinct in western cinema. Pixar films look impeccable nowadays, but in my eyes, nothing will beat the likes of Ghibli's frame-by-frame animation.As for Coco, it's a very solid film and it sure does capture the essence of Mexican culture, although I didn't find the story to be as ground-breaking as I may anticipated given its acclaim; the plot was too convenient at times and I personally missed a little bit more humor every now and then. All in all, a joyful and very necessary movie.

Tiempo de fiesta!The Land of the Dead, skeletons, murders? This can only mean one thing - Disney and Pixar have created another family friendly offering. The 19th offering from the super studio is Coco, based on the Mexican holiday Día de Muertos (Day of the Dead) and following the story of Miguel Rivera (Gonzalez), a twelve-year-old aspiring musician desperate to fulfil his musical dreams. His family are deadset against his ambitions becoming reality and so Miguel takes things into…

I realize that as I grow older, I have less patience with animated family movies. I’m starting to lose that childhood magic and can’t help but get bothered by tiny details and inconsistencies. The first 20 minutes of Coco worried me because I found myself getting annoyed by a lot. But then somehow, I got into it and for a moment I forgot about everything else. The people at Pixar are sorcerers. Coco is pure magic and it WILL warm up your soul whether you let it or not.

It’s such a beautiful feeling to see your culture being represented so beautifully on-screen. Suddenly all the conversations, remarks, comments that my mom had made about Día de los Muertos came into focus. As familiar as the sugar skulls, altars, and papel picado are to me, and many others, seeing them in this film made them feel like they were mine, like it was a moment I was sharing with my family.Also, that shot of Miguel entering the Land of the Dead was absolutely stunning.

Coco is a fully fleshed out and realized project unlike The Good Dinosaur, original as can be despite the complaints that it’s too much like The Book of Life aesthetically, and not a pointless sequel to make a quick million dollars. With their much lauded Inside Out, Pixar developed upon an abstract idea within a metaphysical world, transcending the norm of animated feature films. Coco is the latest film from the Pixar umbrella with Toy Story 3 direct Lee Unkrich helming this animated feature which has us following a young boy in Mexico named Miguel Rivera. Miguel loves his family but there’s one thing he loves just as much…playing music. The problem for Miguel is that there’s a family ban on music that has been passed down for generations because his great-great-grandmother’s husband, a musician, left her and her daughter Coco to pursue a…

"Nothing is more important than family."Aided by scintillating visuals and catchy music, Coco tells the tale of ten year old Miguel, who gets trapped in the Land of the Dead and must find his great-great-grandfather and seek his blessings so that he can return to his village in Mexico.What an absolutely stunning film. It started out slow, but when it picked up, it was unstoppable. There is just SO much heart in it, and by the end I…

90/100Coco delivers in every aspect that Pixar is known for: breathtaking animation, infectious original songwriting, and emotional heft. As for the Mexican culture, though I am white I grew up in Southern California and live currently in San Antonio so I have a basic understanding, Coco appears to hit the nail on the head without sensationalizing it or bearing down the story with it. The story doesn't go to many great lengths and some things are almost too silly for adults, but Coco will win over one and all whose heart is beating. There's nothing quite like family.

More driven by too-clean, too-familiar screenwriting 101 mechanics than inspired directly and defined by Mexican culture. "Our family was torn apart by [MUSIC] and brought together again by [SHOES]." The design is gorgeous, lush, and more deeply textured than any other animation I've seen. Denim, velvet, gingham, plaster, corn husks, all of them have the fine detail of the real thing.The ending got me choked up like everyone, but I've seen Alzheimer's and senility first hand and the film's sudden cure is a rose-tinted fantasy for an existential horror.

Coco is the latest Pixar feature that offers a glimpse into our personal connections with our ancestors. In the film, our main character, an aspiring musician with disapproving parents end up running away on a journey that connects him with his ancestors during the Day of the Dead ceremony. The fleeting idea of mortality and lost love is wonderfully captured amidst colorful animation and vibrant characters, in contrast with the lifeless exterior they are provided.Personally, I empathize with the…

The first movie tears of 2017 have been shed, and it only took a masterpiece. Saw this the afternoon my family attended a memorial mass for my grandparents--maybe that's irony or a coincidence, but whatever the case, it feels both destined and deeply prophetic. Pixar still has it, anchoring beautiful visuals to a tightly-knit (good lord, is this a perfect example of setups and callbacks) fable of family remembrance. When it all came together, it sang, literally. I haven't cried like that since Bing-Bong died, and I probably won't again until...well, the next one. Hopefully.

В этом мультфильме видно как Пиксар умеет тщательно и с любовью подходить к своему творению. Коко нам предлагает прекрасную историю, которая базируется на семейных отношениях и способна затронуть миллионы сердец. Обычный зритель мало, что знает о дне мертвых, но авторы демонстрируют эту тему доступно и эмоционально. Как и проработка истории и героев на высшем уровне. Это реально как будто фильм, но в прекрасном визуальном стиле, на который способна лиш анимация. В общем, это действительно мини шедевр, что по финалу никого не оставит равнодушным. 10/10

Staggeringly beautiful. One of the few modern Disney film to capture the wonder and awe that the opening card used to inspire in me, as a kid. The first sweep across the marigold bridge into the city of the dead is one of the most singularly exquisite visual spectacles displayed in cinema in my lifetime. Touching, at times punishingly evocative, funny, and so, so sweet. An achievement, to be sure.

For those of you who don’t know, the Letterboxd Season Challenge is a community event on here where every week, participants watch a movie from a certain set of guidelines. This is my third year doing it, and it’s really fun; it forces me to both step outside my comfort zone and finally sit down and watch some classics I’d been putting off. This week, though, the criteria was to watch the most popular movie on the Letterboxd Top 250 I hadn’t seen yet.Which is why I just watched Coco in 2020. It’s fine.

This review may contain spoilers. I can handle the truth.  Coco is above-average Pixar fare, with good animation and voice acting. It drags on in parts and has a predictable twist villain, but it makes up for it with its beautiful representation of culture, its great music, and its strong message/emotional core. There was even a tear-jerking moment. Overall, Coco is a sweet and beautiful film, but its cliche plot elements and humor that doesn't always land make it a bit flawed. 8/10

A young Mexican boy, forbidden to express his musical talent by family strictures, is temporarily transported to the land of the dead to reclaim his musical heritage. And strangely enough, through the magic of Pixar/Disney's most effective, large scale animation design since Inside Out, the film works as an emotionally resonant, epic coming of age story.

I cried.This one's all about loss, memory, family, and legacy. It's something that wouldn't have hit me so hard earlier in life. But now, as a man who lost his parents and then became one himself a few years later, the full weight of this story pressed on my chest until I couldn't hold it in any longer. I wept through the final moments of Coco, but I could feel it building the entire third act.Also, what a thoughtful, articulate, gorgeous rendering of the culture and people surrounding Dia de Muertos.

A deeply moving film about family and the importance of loving & remembering your family no matter what.

Coco feels more like a Disney endeavor than a Pixar one - namely, it's safe and formulaic. Sadly, Pixar has been on a steady downtick of originality since around Cars 2 in 2011. And don't tell me Inside Out was an original idea, because I know about Cranium Command, and so does Pete Docter, Inside Out's director. Speaking of Inside Out, Coco lifts a significant plot point from it, as well as a plot twist from Up. Luckily, there's stunning animation to help distract from the sloppy, conventional plotting, as well as emotional beats that effectively strum the heartstrings.

Genuinely terrific, deserves the "well, duh" choice for Best Animated feature this year. As much as I've grown a distaste for the Disney conglomerate recently, my scorn certainly does not extend to PIXAR, and this is their most accomplished effort in a long time.

Pixar are on a higher plain of filmmaking than every other animation studio, even your Studio Ghiblis and Laikas. They make films that not only look incredible, but make you laugh and cry. There doing a service to children worldwide, providing them with quality entertainment that widens their worldview, introduces them to new cultures and helps them to understand complex emotions. Inside Out was a masterpiece. Coco isn’t far behind. Beautifully animated, vibrant, colourful, funny, fucking heart wrenching at times; everything you could want in a movie. Plus any film that features El Santo wins massive brownie points with me.

Like, Miguel’s parents and his abuela and their draconian ban on music (vs. his dream of being a musician) aren’t just a cliche, but a cliche executed in an especially blunt and hamfisted manner, without so much as an attempt at nuance, and the believe-in-yourself/remember-where-you-came-from/family-is-important messaging is both generic and laid on awfully thick. Devastatingly beautiful.A kid, Miguel, wants to be a musician, but his family hates music because his great great grandfather left his wife and daughter to pursue a musical career.This happens on Dia de los Muertos, Day of the Dead. Everything that happens from then is Pixar wonder.

Not only is it an enormously fun and enjoyable family adventure, but it's a film with unbelievable visuals, a characterful and memorable soundtrack, as well as a whole lot of pure, heartfelt emotion that put me right on the edge of tears on more than one occasion. Pixar have always been renowned for their ability to tug at your heartstrings, but what they do with Coco is take the emotional side of the story to another level.This isn't so…

Though it lacks originality in terms of narrative progression it more than leaps in originality for subject matter. Tackling heavier subjects like death and the afterlife, loss and family unity. I was surprised how thoughtful the film wound up being for a kids film. Hopefully this is a sign of Pixar being back on its game and as always the film is beautifully realized on a visual front. Don't miss out on this one even though you have to sit through a god awful Frozen short to reach it.

Once you get past the 21-minute Frozen "short" that screens before the feature — truly one of the classic blunders; the most famous of which is "Never get involved in a land war in Asia," you can relax and enjoy one of Pixar's top-five films.An avalanche of color and light, Coco's easily top-five Pixar in my estimation. It's funny and moving; truly beautiful. Another great score from Mr. Giacchino - who I'm pretty sure is memorialized as de la Cruz's orchestra conductor.

Coco (2017) is an imaginative and magical film. It tells the story of a young Mexican boy who wants to be a musician but is forbidden by his family. On the day of the dead, he is unexpectedly transported to the land of the dead and goes on a surprising and enlightening journey which could forever change him and his family, both alive and dead. The animation is spectacularly beautiful and the film looks gorgeous. It is vibrant, alive, and…

Coco when you boil it down is really nothing new. It's the Pixar formula of two unlikely people going on a journey and becoming friends along the way. Then mix that in with a sadly basic message of "family" and also every misunderstood teenage musician film you've seen. Take that along with the usual great Pixar animation, and of course great music and voice acting, and you have something that's above the line for Pixar, but not as memorable as…

Pixar does it - yet again. I really didn't know how much I was going to like this movie going into it. Was worried that it wasn't going to offer me many surprises. Boy, was I wrong. Man, everything delivers in this film. Some great voice work by the young lead…

Incredibly heartfelt and soulful. I fought back many tears, but alas - my flood-gates opened! This movie was really well-crafted, from its captivating animation to its vibrant color pallet and stellar direction. This was a very unique story.This film meditates on what it means to be truly forgotten. It’s only when everyone you've known dies that you truly cease to exist... Which is why we tell stories, they're extensions of ourselves that others will remember once we've passed on.96/100Deep stuff.

No veo películas de animacion, no me gustan, pero con Coco he conectado con una de ellas como no lo hacía desde Toy Story 3. Independientemente del trato de Mexico y el Día de Muertos, me impresiona muy para bien la manera tan sencilla en que te plantean las cosas que verdaderamente importan en la vida.

#Coco: Nos brinda una colorida, divertida y emotiva historia de Día de los Muertos, llena de referencias y alegorías mexicanas, aunque es innegable el uso de estereotipos para la creación del mundo de Coco. Es agradable el poder disfrutar de una película animada que logra representar con respeto no solamente una festividad, sino también a un país lleno de cultura como lo es México. El extenso y detallado trabajo que realizó Pixar, en especial sus directores (Lee Unkrich y Adrián…

Cocouuu Es una historia completa. Te ríes, lloras, sientes un vínculo especial con los personajes y te deja un buen menaje, ademas de la que la película está preciosa, llena de naranja cempasúchil, sin mencionar la música preciosa. Para mi logra captar mucha esencia de México a través de muchísimos detalles que hacen que la historia genere un vínculo especial con cualquier mexicano.

Sometimes I think I’m a pretty strong person and then I rewatch Coco and cry for 30 minutes. This movies is beautiful, sad, and depicts death and memory is such vivid strokes that it’s impossible not be swept up in the story being told with incredible visuals and fantastic music.Memory is a powerful thing and I love the idea that memory of love is as powerful as anything which makes me hopeful and absolutely crushes me at the same time. Those final moments of the film are magic. One of my favourite Pixar films.

Fantastisch komponiert und animiert. Die emotionale Tiefe der Storyline über Familienbande und das Streben nach der Verwirklichung eigener Träume ist bemerkenswert. Musik und Handlung tragen durch ihre symbiotische Relation zur kulturellen Authentizität des Films bei. Somit ist Coco insgesamt ein absolut liebenswerter und herzerwärmender Film über Zusammenhalt und Erinnerung, der zudem eine durchaus adäquate Darstellung der mexikanischen Dia de los Muertos-Tradition bietet.

It was a grim Thanksgiving. We are shrinking in numbers and my elderly mother was determined to remind us at every possible turn just how many people she knew who were dead now.In desperation, my sibling put Coco on, which had the benefit of shutting my mother up and being quite wonderful. I thought I knew where it was going several times and I kept on being surprised. And by the end I was crying and was transported.
I was not immune.

Probably Pixar's most visually inventive film, while also being one of its most emotionally striking. It respectfully utilizes the established culture and lore of the Dia de Los Muertos to create an entire fantasy society based upon it. From the border control to the blessings and the final death, everything makes sense…

The themes of pursuing one's passions despite adversity, family ties, family love, culture traditions, and resonating lifetime memories passed down with each generation naturally creates an emotionally rich animated film that made me cry. The Day of the Dead is one of the most notable Mexican holidays. Despite this, only few films have been made about it. One of these films is Coco.Miguel Rivera wants to become a musician like his idol, Ernesto De La Cruz. However, his family doesn’t allow music. Disney / Pixar’s COCO blends a story of love, family and music like no other animated movie that I’ve seen to date. Coco tells the story of a boy who’s longing to play music. He also starts unlocking his family tree and it’s many traditions.  Not too many animated movies go as deep into the feels like this movie did. I was constantly enthralled by the story of this film and the overall look of this movie was GORGEOUS!The characters…

Offering dazzling city and sights yet unseen in modern digital animation, as well as a loving (if slightly shopworn) fable about legacy and rememberance, Pixar's Coco is a reminder of what animation is capable of when the filmmakers venture outside of the box and dream something wild. The world of the Dead is packed with neon shimmer and detail. The pathos are well earned. And the voice cast, which mixes in newcomers as well as seasoned veterans, is up to the task of populating this tale with heartfelt personality and levity. I wish Disney animation followed suit with this sort of visual imagination.

I watched this in the theater and I loved it for everything about it. Funny characters, an immersive cultural experience, beautiful animation, and a entertaining plot. Pixar created another masterpiece with this film, and in my opinion, knocked it even more out of the park than they usually do (see my Pixar ranking for further reference).

Не буду говорить про традиционное невероятное качество анимации у Pixar, к этому за годы мы уже привыкли, но вот песни — помню, ещё очень долго слушал их в оригинале после первого просмотра мультфильма.Отдельных похвал заслуживает великолепный дизайн города мёртвых. Charming, with a surprisingly rich script. This is a children's movie where spirits disappear forever when they're completely forgotten. Being absolutely forgotten is one of the most terrifying things in a bone-deep, existential way. It's a very emotional film, but also Frida Kahlo's show made me bust a gut. The tone is well-managed with the laughs not glib or childish and the emotional moments not overwrought. "Un Poco Loco" slaps. It seems like the official Cry Moment is Miguel singing "Remember Me" to Mama Coco, but I got the feels when Hector was finally able to cross over the bridge.

Remember Me is a good song and all but fuck, it didn’t deserve to win over Mystery of Love. The animation is gorgeous, and it’s message on family and their importance and impact on your life is pretty powerful, but outside of that, it’s predictable & a somewhat weak effort from Pixar compared to their other films. And to be honest, I’ve already forgotten most of it.

Warm colors evolve into a bright remembrance of faded love and lost memories. Hues pop in the vibrations of the music connecting generations. Pixar at its most colorfully playful, weaving such strong musically-visual emotion into every beat; Lee Unkrich is clearly the animated maestro of accepting death and knowing life is more beautiful surrounded by who you love, with each moment powered by what you love. That this is a bit low in my personal Pixar ranking only speaks to how incredible this studio is. Greatness has great company.

The only problem is that music is forbidden in his household. He ends up stumbling into the land of the dead, coming face to face with…

Por primera vez Pixar toma uno de los riesgos más importantes a lo largo de su trayectoria adentrándonos a un universo y una cultura que ellos desconocen, si bien Coco nos cuenta una vez más "El Camino del Héroe" lo interesante es ver cómo nos lo cuenta. Por alguna extraña razón, me sentía escéptico a 'Coco'. No la vi cuando se estrenó en 2017 y hasta apenas le di una oportunidad. Afortunadamente, me algreo de haberlo hecho. Como Mexicano, puedo decir que la cultura de México esta bien representada, y, justo por esto, conecté profundamente con la película. Ya se ha dicho mucho de ella, pero me encantó que mantiene la ideología que Pixar ha venido sosteniendo a lo largo del tiempo con la mayoría de sus producciones: ser unicos, diferentes, no conformistas, sin importar que todo al rededor esté en contra.

7. Watch one of the 5 most popular films on your watchlist.Coco made me laugh, cry, and look forward to dying. It’s certainly the best family film I’ve seen in a long time. There’s so many good things about it: the visuals are utterly beautiful but it’s not superficial, the pacing of the plot with its twists is perfect, the child protagonist is sweet with understandable motives, and most importantly to me every emotional moment feels earned. I hate when emotion is forced upon the viewer, particularly in kids films, but everything in Coco hit me just right.

Now this is Disney firing on all cylinders with a story's potential. One thing I've always loved about Disney is their fascination with death, and how they never really shy away from it. Whether it be the likes of Mufasa's demise, the parents (or villain's final moments) in Tarzan, or even just the constant impaling of any invincible side character, they embrace it as an important part of life. And that theme is something Pixar seem more than keen to…

I thought maybe it could have been more high-concept throughout the film, as Inside Out achieved, instead of turning into your typical talent show storylines and random encounters. On the other hand, an ending that could make a grown man cry saved this film half a star.If you want a family film that can perfectly and gorgeously teach any child about the fragility of death and importance of memory, watch Kubo & the Two Strings. If you want a fun-filled, colourful, exciting Pixar film with a touching ending, watch Coco.

I kept waiting for Manny Calavera to show up!A bit of a misfire for Pixar, although they've done much worse. The pacing of the first hour or so is appalling and quite honestly I was getting bored. The characters are not particularly rounded, the story is very bland and the humour is severely under par for what Pixar are usually able to do.Then the last 20 minutes or so happened and my heart was overwhelmed. I'm not crying,…

The movie takes a long time setting up some pretty paint-by-numbers backstory in the first act, before finally crossing the action over into the City of the Dead. But once it gets there, it's pure fun and emotion. The logistics of how the Day of the Dead works are wonderfully accomplished--worldbuilding that doesn't feel tedious, but entertaining. The series of reveals are predictable, but manage to seem organically inevitable, instead of face-smackingly obvious. And the end is the best kind of Pixar tearjerking. I wish it had started out stronger, but it ended on a high note.

Watched At : Odeon What!! A Disney film that I didn't really enjoy. How is that possible? The premise of the story was a fascinating one before I went in. I just never got a real kick out of it. Well this was lovely, wasn't it? Makes the whole Day of the Dead thing sound like something everybody should be doing, all while positing a fantastical, celebratory afterlife that still makes room for a spooky, sad, inevitable unknown.

This fell pretty short of greatness for me, which is disappointing given Lee Unkrich's involvement, but Coco is nevertheless another reliably charming, visually stunning, affecting Pixar animation.The main thing holding this back is that the premise lacks the cleverness of, say, Toy Story, Monsters Inc or Inside Out; the mechanics of the life/death aren't especially fresh, and the main theme of "family is everything" feels fairly trite, even corny, to me, especially with how many high-profile movies have tried…

The experience of watching Coco was, to me, one of the best experiences I ever had with a Pixar film. Whilst gathering heavy issues from the political real world and transforming it into a great message of family and unity, this film showcases Pixar's best form from the script to cinematography. Immerse in a vivid purple, the world from the death in Coco has many celebrities from the real world, and is just as rich as any setting in movies.…

Fantastic. Excellent job, Pixar! I loved this film from start to finish. Though some parts of the plot were a little predictable, there were a few good twists as well.The colors, music, graphics, and use of culture and language were outstanding. Disney/Pixar needs to continue on this path of storytelling. I’d take 50 Coco’s before a single Frozen sequel. God I loved this. Definitely plan to see it again, I was teary eyed mess by the end, and honestly so relieved how nicely it was executed. Viva la Coco!

É preciso dizer que a Pixar acertou de novo. E acertou em cheio.“Viva- A Vida é Uma Festa” é um dos filmes mais coloridos e inclusivos do estúdio. Embora não tenha a sagacidade de “Divertida Mente”, meu favorito, tem personagens carismáticos e um elenco de dubladores impecável. Ambientado no México, mas precisamente na celebração do “Dia dos Mortos”, a animação recicla as clássicas histórias com apelo familiar e mesmo que não pareça original, algumas outras animações recentes já abordaram…

Beautifully animated and entertaining but not as great as everyone is making it be. There were some beautiful songs and the voice acting was also pretty good but the concept or the execution was nothing new. As for an animated film that concerns about Day of the Dead I prefer The Book of Life. There were some obvious attempts at some political commentary that fell flat for me. The story was also quite predictable nonetheless a fun watch where they kept their respect for the culture.
Beautiful animation and enjoyable characters. The emotional third act made the film for me. Loved the guitar.

Just as good the second time. Possibly my favorite Pixar movie. Gets easily as emotional - if not more so - than Toy Story 3, but doesn't have the benefit of three movies of character build up. Yet everything that it sets up is perfectly deserving and heartfelt.

The animation in Coco is gorgeous - let's get that out of the way first. The movie has the standard "be yourself" moral, but as you can imagine, the team at Pixar finds nuances the play with that most studios wouldn't notice. I can't speak to how faithful the film is to Mexican culture, but it's great seeing that diversity in story, storytelling, and even storytellers. Pixar movies tend to make me cry, but I was weepy throughout the last ten minutes of Coco. Good work.

“Know that I’m with you the only way that I can be...”in my mind, this lovely, vibrant spiritual musical earns a spot among the ranks of Pixar’s best. while its adherence to the classic hero’s journey threatens to feel a tad bit formulaic at times, Coco nevertheless delivers a compelling narrative that engages timeless themes with energy and stunning visual flair, achieving genuine pathos through a downright beautiful meditation on love, loss, and family. from what I’ve heard at least,…
Not bad, not my favorite. The animation is great but the story felt very Corpse Bride, but with music. The music is very good so that’s not bad.
